reference_no_or_id: Criminal Appeal No. 553 of 1958, Appeal No. 64 of 1959
complaint_summary: The murder of Sajwara was reported by Fazil (P.W. 7) following a blood feud involving longstanding enmity between the families.
investigation_summary: Police recovered blood-stained chhavi and shirt from Khuda Yar. Witnesses Khan and Fazil provided testimony corroborated by physical evidence.
judgment_summary: The Supreme Court upheld Khuda Yar's conviction for the murder of Sajwara based on corroborated evidence, dismissing the appeal. Acquittal of other accused was maintained due to lack of sufficient evidence.

punishment.commuted: Transportation for life under general amnesty

legal_arguments: Defense argued injuries on Khan were fabricated.
Prosecution relied on corroboration from blood-stained evidence and witness testimony.
Defense raised weapon discrepancy between spear and chhavi.
Delay in FIR filing was justified due to distance traveled.

witness_statement.Khan: Saw the assault on Sajwara and sustained injuries.
witness_statement.Fazil: Reported the incident to police and corroborated Khan's account.
witness_statement.Dara: Provided evidence of recovery of blood-stained items.
witness_statement.Rana Abdur Rahman: Recovered broken pitcher and corroborated evidence.

facts.location: Village outskirts near Amir butcher's house

key_points: Recovery of blood-stained items corroborated guilt
FIR delay justified due to distance traveled
court_findings.acquittal_reasoning: Benefit of doubt extended to other accused (Khan, Basara, Gahra)

words_and_phrases.Blood feud: Longstanding enmity between families leading to acts of revenge.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the murder of Sajwara, allegedly committed by Khuda Yar due to a blood feud. The conviction was upheld based on corroborated evidence, including blood-stained items and witness testimony. The appeal was dismissed, and the sentence commuted to life imprisonment under general amnesty.
